active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the following: 'Is penetration testing sufficient for testing HIPAA technical safeguards, or should it always be combined with risk assessments and audit reviews? Use examples from NIST SP 800-66 and a recent healthcare breach to support your position.' Encourage critical thinking by requiring participants to reference voter-suggested mappings to NIST CSF functions.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in HIPAA Security Rule Testing (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > 008_Application Security > Web 008_Application Security > 021_Security Testing Methodologies > Compliance and Certification Testing > HIPAA Security Rule Testing). Use the provided research context: HIPAA Security Rule requires administrative, physical, and technical safeguards for ePHI (electronic protected health information) in covered entities and business associates. NIST SP 800-66 Rev 2 maps these to cybersecurity practices; NIST CSF functions: Identify (risk mgmt), Protect (access controls), Detect (auditing), Respond/Recover (plans). Sources: https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/sp/800/66/r2/final, https://www.hhs.gov/hipaa/for-professionals/security/guidance/index.html, https://www.nist.gov/cyberframework. Incorporate these pedagogical elements: - Learning Objectives: [insert array above] - Scaffolding: Generate cards tagged by 4 layers [insert scaffolding details]. - Active Learning: Weave in prompts (e.g., 'Apply to discussion scenario'). - Prerequisites: Assume knowledge of HIPAA Privacy Rule and basic testing methodologies. - Concept Map: Ensure cards reflect hierarchical relationships (Safeguards → Testing → NIST CSF). Generate flashcards per schema: [insert schema details]. Balance: 20% REMEMBER/UNDERSTAND (Layer 1-2), 30% APPLY/ANALYZE (Layer 2-3), 30% EVALUATE (Layer 3), 20% CREATE (Layer 4). Voter consensus: Emphasize testing methodologies for all safeguards with NIST mappings. Output ONLY a JSON array of flashcards: [{'front': '...', 'back': {...}}]. Ensure university-level rigor, active recall, and spaced repetition optimization.
